1272.03
   1249.01   FINDINGS; PURPOSE; INTENT.
   It is hereby determined that: (i) continuing development within the City has
placed a strain on the City's parks and other recreational facilities; (ii) the
City requires additional revenues to provide the residents of the City with
appropriate recreational facilities; and (iii) a portion of the burden should
be borne by the developers and purchasers, who are incidentally but not totally
responsible, and the remaining share of the cost should be borne by the
residents of the City, who will also be using the facilities. The fees assessed
pursuant to this chapter, along with monies derived from other Municipal funds,
shall be used for the planning, acquisition, improvement and expansion of
public parks, playgrounds and other recreational facilities to serve the
increasing growth and development of the City. It is the purpose of this
chapter to assure that new development bears a proportionate share of the cost
of expenditures necessary to provide such recreational facilities in the City.
It is Council's intention that the fees collected pursuant to this chapter
shall be supplemented by appropriations from the general revenue and committed
to park and recreation purposes.
(Ord. 00-19.  Passed 6-12-00.)
   1249.02  DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   "Commercial space" means each space, area or building that is intended
for any use permitted in a B-l, B-2, B-3 or B-4 zoning district, other than any
space, area or building that is used for public uses.
   (b)   "Dwelling" shall have the same meaning given to such term in Section
1260.06(46) of the Codified Ordinances of the City of Vermilion.
   (c)   "Dwelling, multiple" shall have the same meaning given to such term in
Section
1260.06(47) of the Codified Ordinances of the City of Vermilion.
   (d)   "Dwelling, single-family" shall have the same meaning given to such
term in Section
1260.06(48) of the Codified Ordinances of the City of Vermilion.
   (e)   "Dwelling, two-family" shall have the same meaning given to such term
in Section
 1260.06(49) of the Codified Ordinances of the City of Vermilion.
   (f)   "Dwelling unit" shall have the same meaning given to such term in
Section
1260.06(50) of the Codified Ordinances of the city of Vermilion.
   (g)   "Industrial space" means each space, area, or building that is
intended for any use permitted in an I-1, I-2 or I-3 zoning district, other
than any space, area or building that is used for public uses.
   (h)   "Person" means every person or legal entity who or which engages in
construction activities itself or through the services of any employee, agent
or independent contractor.
   (i)   "Public uses" shall have the same meaning given to such term in
Section
1260.06(86) of the Codified Ordinances of the City of Vermilion.
      (Ord. 00-19.  Passed 6-12-00.)
   1249.03   CONSTRUCTION FEES.
   In addition to all other fees prescribed by the Codified Ordinances of the
City of Vermilion, every person constructing in the City of Vermilion: a new
dwelling unit; a new commercial space; a new industrial space; an addition of
1,000 square feet or more to an existing commercial space; or an addition of
1,000 square feet or more to an existing industrial space; shall pay to the
City fees for park and recreation purposes as follows:
   (a)   $400.00 for each new single-family dwelling;
   (b)   $350.00 for each new dwelling unit in a two-family dwelling;
   (c)   $350.00 for each new dwelling unit in a multi-family dwelling;
   (d)   $100.00 for every 1,000 square feet, or portion thereof on a prorated
basis, of new commercial space or for an addition of at least 1,000 square feet
to existing commercial space; and
   (e)   $100.00 for every 1,000 square feet, or portion thereof on a prorated
basis, of new industrial space or for an addition of at least 1,000 square feet
to existing industrial space.
      (Ord. 00-19.  Passed 6-12-00.)
   1249.04   PAYMENT OF FEES.
   The fees set forth in Section
1249.03 shall be due and payable upon the issuance of a building permit by the
City of Vermilion for the construction described in such section; provided
however, that such fees shall be refunded in the event the building permit is
not used for such construction.
(Ord. 00-19.  Passed 6-12-00.)
   1249.05  PARK IMPROVEMENT FUND; MATCHING AMOUNT.
   There shall be paid into the Park Improvement Fund (Fund No. 204):
   (a)   The fees required by this chapter and all income derived from such
fees;
   (b)   Gifts, bequests and legacies made to the Park Improvement Fund and all
income derived from such gifts, bequests and legacies; and
   (c)   An amount collected by the City for such purposes from real property
taxes, which amount shall in no event be less than the fees deposited in the
Park Improvement Fund during the preceding year.
      (Ord. 00-19.  Passed 6-12-00.)
   1249.06   USE OF FUNDS.
   All moneys in the Park Improvement Fund shall be used as allocated by the
Council of the City of Vermilion solely for the following purposes:
   (a)   Purchase of land and interests in land for recreational purposes;
   (b)   Development of parks and construction or improvement of buildings for
recreational purposes;
   (c)   Acquisition and development of other varieties of open space for
recreational purposes;
   (d)   Acquisition and development of bicycle trails, riding trails, and
other types of trails for recreational use; and
   (e)   Acquisition and development of recreation facilities constructed or
acquired after the passage of this chapter.
      (Ord. 00-19.  Passed 6-12-00.)

   1250.01   PROCEDURE FOR APPROVAL.
   After approval for recording of the dedication plat by the Planning
Commission, the following procedure shall be followed:
   (a)   The engineer of the subdivision shall consult the City Engineer as to
the engineering details required for all improvements. The requirement of
street lighting facilities, either underground or above ground, shall be
recommended and approved by the City Engineer and the Commission. In fulfilling
such obligation, the subdivider shall plan or cause to be planned the
installation of street lighting facilities pursuant to certain agreements
between the subdivider and the electric utility company which are consonant
with any existing contracts between the City and such utility company. The
subdivider is required to grant unto such utility company all easements
necessary for the initial installation, operation and maintenance of street
lighting facilities, all of which shall be accomplished before the final
acceptance of such subdivision.
      Where the subdivision is outside the City and within the three-mile limit
of subdivision jurisdiction and the plans for the subdivision call for the
installation of septic tanks for sanitary disposal or central sewage treatment
facilities, an additional print shall be sent to the Lorain or Erie County
Board of Health or the Lorain or Erie County Sanitary Engineer for report and
approval.
   (b)   After the plan has been reviewed by the City Engineer and other
concerned agencies and the design details and requirements have been
satisfactorily met, it shall be reported back by letter to the Commission.
   (c)   The plan, signed by the City Engineer, together with the signature of
the Director of Public Service regarding the improvements, shall be transmitted
to the Commission.
   (d)   After final approval by the Commission, the plan shall be signed by
the Chairman and returned to the City Engineer.
   (e)   The City Engineer shall have a mylar tracing made of the final plan.
The cost of the plan shall be charged against the fund deposited by the
subdivider. The original tracing shall be recorded by the City Engineer.
   (f)   Before any subdivision plat or construction plan is given final
approval, the subdivider or developer shall have executed a subdivider's
agreement with the City of Vermilion or any other applicable city or county
department, acting through the City Engineer as its agent.
   (g)   A performance bond for the amount of the construction and inspection
costs as estimated by the City Engineer shall be deposited with the Clerk of
Council before authorization of any construction. In lieu of the performance
bond, a certified check in the amount of ninety percent of the estimated
construction cost shall be accepted. Upon final approval of the construction
plans, four sets of prints shall be required for the use of the City Engineer.
      (Ord. 79-20. Passed 8-6-79.)
   1250.02  CHARGES FOR REVIEW OF ENGINEERING DETAILS AND FIELD INSPECTION.
   (a)   In compliance with the rules and regulations of the Planning
Commission, it is established that the charge against any private improvement
project shall be based on the actual time spent in review of such plans and
inspection services provided during construction, as determined from the time
records of the Engineer. Costs are to be computed on the basis of the rates on
file with the Clerk of Council.
 
   (b)   The subdivider, or his agent, is required to deposit with the Building
Department a sum of money, in an amount to be determined by the City Engineer
for each application, before a plan will be considered for approval. (Rates
recorded in minutes of the Commission.)
 
   (c)   In the event the subdivider desires to contest the estimate of costs
submitted by the City Engineer, he may do so by appealing to the Commission
within ten days from the date of the estimate, and the Commission shall make
the final decisions, after having evidence from both sides, at the next
regularly scheduled meeting subsequent to the date of appeal. The appeal shall
be in writing.  (Ord. 2003-18.  Passed 4-7-03.)
   1250.03  CONSTRUCTION PLANS GENERALLY.
   This section is intended to enable a developer or his or her engineer to
prepare his or her construction plans so that the review and approval thereof
will be expedited.
   (a)   Developers of subdivisions are required to indicate on the drawing the
engineering details of all existing and proposed facilities and services, which
include street pavements, sidewalks, sanitary and storm sewers, water and gas
mains and street lighting facilities. Such facilities and services shall be
designed by an engineer who must be a registered professional engineer in the
State. The  State of Ohio, Department of Transportation, Construction and
Material Specifications, January 1, 1975, edition, as amended, and the Division
of Highways, Bureau of Roadway Design, Standard Construction Drawing, as
amended by Council, shall be followed, except where they specifically deviate
from other ordinances duly enacted by the City. The location of public
utilities and specifically street lighting facilities shall initially be
planned and cooperatively agreed upon among the City Engineer, the Planning
Commission and the developer. As a part of the required public improvement
facilities within a subdivision, the subdivider, in areas where overhead
utilities are permitted, shall cause to be planned street lighting facilities
within the public right of way and shall submit drawings to the City Engineer
in such form as can be forwarded to the electric utility company in order that
such company can plan, locate and install street lighting facilities. No street
lighting post, pole or pedestal shall be installed or illuminated until the
City Engineer orders the same pursuant to the approved plan therefor. While it
is not the obligation of the subdivider to pay for such facilities, the
subdivider is obligated to cause the street lighting facilities to be planned
in a manner acceptable to the City Engineer. Where underground utilities are
required henceforth, the subdivider shall cause to be planned and shall pay for
hollow core pole lighting facilities within the dedicated right of way and
shall submit drawings to the City Engineer in such form as can be forwarded to
the electric utility company in order that such company can plan, locate and
install street lighting facilities. No street lighting post, pole or pedestal
shall be installed or illuminated until the City Engineer orders the same
pursuant to the approved plan therefor. Such hollow core street lighting
facilities shall be included as a required subdivision improvement, the expense
of which shall be borne by the subdivider. Such facilities shall be planned
prior to the final acceptance of such subdivision and its improvements by
Council, but shall not be a cause to delay the subdivider at preliminary stages
so long as adequate drawings and plans have been submitted to the City Engineer
upon which he or she and the electric utility company can locate street
lighting facilities. The subdivider shall grant to the electric utility company
any easements necessary for the installation, operation and maintenance of such
street lighting facilities. (Ord. 86-14. Passed 6-2-86.)
   (b)   Each plat or plan, when filed with public authorities for review and
approval, shall bear the stamp or the seal prescribed by the State Board of
Registration for Professional Engineers and Surveyors. Plans not bearing such
stamp shall not be given consideration.
   (c)   All elevations shown on the construction plan shall be referenced to
the City Bench Mark System or the U.S. Coast and Geodetic Bench Mark System,
where possible. Location and elevation of bench marks shall be shown on the
plan.
   (d)   All drawings shall be made on sheets twenty-four by thirty-six inches
in size out to out of the trimming edge.
   (e)   The plan shall be drawn to a scale of forty feet to the inch. The
profile shall be to the same scale horizontally and four feet to the inch
vertically. An enlarged drawing to show details shall be made where necessary.
   (f)   Location and size of all existing features shall be shown as well as
any other data which may be pertinent for the City Engineer in reviewing or
checking the plans.
   (g)   The title of the plan shall contain the name of the subdivision, the
names of streets, roads and/or courts and the name of the City and the County.
Space shall be provided on the title sheet or the first sheet of the plans for
approval by the proper authorities.
   (h)   Plans and specifications for the proposed installation shall be
approved by the City and the State Environmental Protection Agency for sanitary
sewers and water mains, before construction is started. The City requires the
approval of the City Engineer, the Director of Public Service, the Planning
Commission and Council, in that order of sequence.
   (i)   The approval of construction drawings shall be limited to twelve
months from the date of approval by the Commission, after which time the
approval shall be null and void.
   (j)   Separate drawings shall be made for pavement, water mains, sanitary
sewers and storm sewers. However, a gas main may be shown on the water main
drawing and sidewalks may be shown on the pavement drawing.
      (Ord. 79-20. Passed 8-6-79.)
   1250.04  CONSTRUCTION PLANS; STREETS.
   (a)   Plan. The plan of street improvements in the subdivision shall show
the stations and angles of all intersecting streets and turnarounds, as well as
monument locations.
   All intersecting streets shall have a minimum curb radius of twenty-five
feet.
   Where a proposed street ends in a cul-de-sac, a ball shape turnaround shall
be  required. The minimum radius shall be fifty-five feet, measured to the back
of the curb, and the complete turnaround shall have a reinforced concrete
pavement seven inches thick.
   The limits of the proposed pavement shall be clearly indicated, and all
streets shall be paved within the limits of the subdivision.
(Ord. 2003-52.  Passed 12-15-03.)
   (b)   Roadway Section. The concrete pavement shall be in accordance with the
City of Vermilion Standard Paving Details and Section
 1250.11.
(Ord. 850. Passed 7-1-63.)
   (c)   Sidewalks.
(1)   One-course concrete sidewalks, four feet in width and four inches thick,
shall be constructed in all walkways and on both sides of all streets within
the subdivision. Paving brick may be used in the Harbour Town Historic District
as defined by Council. Specifications shall be approved by the City Engineer.
The paving brick sidewalk shall comply with the City Standards for Brick
Sidewalk Detail.
(2)   Where brick sidewalks are to be laid on existing concrete, detailed
construction drawings shall be presented and approved by the City Engineer,
Planning Commission, Service Director and Council prior to issuance of a
building permit.
   These drawings shall bear the seal of a registered engineer and show in
detail the relative elevations between streets, curbs, sidewalks and buildings.
   All brick utilized under this specification shall be "hard fired paving
brick". See City Standards for Brick Sidewalk Detail.
   (Ord.73-65. Passed 7-23-73.)
   (d)   Connections to Existing Pavements. Details of connections to existing
pavements shall be shown, with particular care to maintain proper grade.
(Ord. 850. Passed 7-1-63.)
   1250.05   CONSTRUCTION PLANS; STORM SEWERS.
   (a)   General Instructions. The developer shall follow the Ohio
Transportation Department publication mentioned in Section
1250.03(a) in providing storm sewers and storm sewer inlets to drain all of the
street intersections and to limit the flow of surface water in the gutters,
before entering the sewer inlet, to approximately 200 feet. Also, facilities
must be provided to care for downspouts by a six-inch diameter line to the
street storm sewer. Yard drains and sump pumps (clean water only) shall be
connected to this storm water line. Driveway aprons may be drained to the
street gutter or the storm water drain line.
(Ord. 76-5. Passed 2-2-76.)
   (b)   Basic Design Data.
(1)   Surface runoff. To determine the quantity of surface runoff for which
capacity should be provided, the State of Ohio, Department of Transportation,
Construction and Material Specifications, January 1, 1975 edition, as amended,
and the Division of Highways, Bureau of Roadway Design, Standard Construction
Drawing, as amended by Council, shall be followed, except where they
specifically deviate from other ordinances duly enacted by the City.
(2)   Intensity of precipitation. The intensity of rainfall shall be determined
from the State of Ohio, Department of Transportation, Construction and Material
Specifications, January 1, 1975 edition, as amended, and the Division of
Highways, Bureau of Roadway Design, Standard Construction Drawing, as amended
by Council, except where they specifically deviate from other ordinances duly
enacted by the City. Use ten year frequency factor.
   (Ord. 75-72A. Passed 9-8-75.)
(3)   Impervious or runoff coefficient. A weighted value of the increment areas
shall be computed, using 0.9 for roof areas and hard surface paved areas, 0.7
for sidewalk and macadam driveways and 0.2 for unpaved areas, yards and lawns.
(Ord. 850. Passed 7-1-63.)
(4)   Size of sewer. The minimum diameter street sewer allowed shall be twelve
inches. (Ord. 74-42. Passed 5-6-74.)
(5)   Depth. Minimum depths for storm sewers shall be three feet of cover and
provide clearance for other utilities.
(6)   Location. Wherever possible, the storm sewers shall be located sixteen
feet from the center line of the street.
   (Ord. 76-5. Passed 2-2-76.)
(7)   Manholes. Manholes shall be placed at intersections and termini of
sewers; at all changes in size, alignment and slope of sewer, in pipe sizes
under thirty-inch diameter; at or near junction chambers and curves on sewers
thirty inches in diameter or larger; at points where inlets are to be
connected; and at intermediate intervals as required for maintenance.
   (c)   Materials and Installation. All materials used and the installation of
those materials shall be in accordance with Section
1250.15.
(Ord. 850. Passed 7-1-63.)
   (d)   City Standards. The storm sewer system shall comply with City
Standards for Storm Sewer Detail, the State of Ohio, Department of
Transportation Construction and Material Specifications, January 1, 1975
edition, as amended, and the Division of Highways, Bureau of Roadway Design,
Standard Construction Drawing, as amended by Council. (Ord. 75-83. Passed 11-
17-75.)
   1250.06  CONSTRUCTION PLANS; SANITARY SEWERS.
   (a)   Basic Design Data.
(1)   Quantity of sewage. The quantity of domestic sewage flow to be provided
for in a separate system of sanitary sewers shall not be less than the
following:
 
A. Lateral   350 g.p.c.d.
B. Sub-trunk 300 g.p.c.d.
C. Trunk     250 g.p.c.d.
 
(2)   Depth. The depth for sanitary sewers shall be as required for the type of
building structure and the elevation of the basement to be served. If a
basement drain is to be served, the depth of the main sewer below the
established grade of the street shall be sufficient to:
         A.   Enable a house lateral laid on a minimum of two percent slope to
have a depth of seven feet at the curb line, measured from the curb grade to
the flow line;
         B.   Provide not less than three feet between the basement elevation
and the hydraulic gradient at the main sewer; and
            (Ord. 850. Passed 7-1-63.)
         C.   Provide a minimum of three feet of earth cover above the sewer
and under the street pavement. (Ord. 74-42. Passed 5-6-74.)
(3)   Location. The sanitary sewer shall be located to avoid conflict with
other utilities on the street.
   (Ord. 76-5. Passed 2-2-76.)
(4)   Manholes. Manholes shall be placed at all intersections of two or more
sewers; at all changes in size of pipe, alignment and grade; at the head end of
the system; and at intermediate intervals of not more than 350 feet.
   (Ord. 850. Passed 7-1-63.)
   (b)   City Standards. The sanitary sewer system shall comply with the City
Standards for Sanitary Sewer Details, the State of Ohio, Department of
Transportation, Construction and Material Specifications, January 1, 1975
edition, as amended, and the Division of Highways, Bureau of Roadway Design,
Standard Construction Drawing, as amended by Council, except where they
specifically deviate from other ordinances duly enacted by the City.
(Ord. 75-72A. Passed 9-8-75.)
   (c)   Materials and Installation. All materials used and the installation of
those materials shall be in accordance with Section
 1250.14.
(Ord. 850. Passed 7-1-63.)
   1250.07   CONSTRUCTION PLANS; WATER MAINS.
   (a)   All materials used and the installation of those materials shall be in
accordance with Section
1250.13. (Ord. 850. Passed 7-1-63.)
   (b)   Fire hydrants shall be placed at a maximum of 300-foot intervals in
residential areas and 200-foot intervals in commercial or industrial areas.
(Ord. 74-42. Passed 5-6-74.)
 
   (c)   There shall be four control valves at each cross-intersection and
three control valves at each tee-intersection, also a valve ahead of each fire
hydrant installation. (Ord. 850. Passed 7-1-63.)
 
   (d)   Water mains shall be located eighteen feet from the center line of the
street or as directed by the City Engineer. Dead ends will not be permitted
where it is possible to obtain a closed circuit to proposed or existing mains.
   All hydrants, plugs, caps, ties, and bends deflecting twenty-two and one-
half degrees or more on mains eight inches or larger in diameter shall be
provided with concrete reaction backing which shall be so placed that joints
will be accessible for repair. Such backing shall be of suitable design and the
details shown on the drawings. (Ord. 76-5. Passed 2-2-76.)
   (e)   The size of water mains to be installed in the new system will be
determined by the City.
 
   (f)   All water service branches from the water mains to the houses will be
installed in accordance with the rules and regulations of the Vermilion Water
Bureau.
 
   (g)   The water line system shall comply with the City of Vermilion
Standards for Waterline Details. (Ord. 850. Passed 7-1-63.)
   1250.08  APPLICATIONS FOR INSPECTION OF CITY IMPROVEMENTS.
   The supervision of all tests and the field inspection of materials and
workmanship shall be performed by the City Engineer, or his representative.
This inspection shall be continuous during the time of construction and the
City shall be reimbursed for the cost of such inspection by the subdivider.
   The contractor for the subdivider is required to notify the City Engineer as
to the date on which the work will start and when a City inspector will be
required. It is necessary that the contractor give the Engineer at least
twenty-four hours notice in each instance where an inspector is to be provided,
except when the inspector will be needed on a Monday, in which case the
notification must be received on the preceding Friday. If an inspector is not
available due to the contractor not complying with the foregoing twenty-four
hours notice, no construction work on the affected project will be permitted. 
   Any defects noted by the City Engineer shall be corrected as directed by the
City Engineer before any further construction work is done.
(Ord. 850. Passed 7-1-63; Ord. 74-42. Passed 5-6-74.)
   1250.09   SURVEY AND PERMANENT MONUMENTS.
   (a)   Location of Survey Monuments. At the time of surveying and laying out
subdivisions or additions to the City, the proprietor of such subdivision or
addition shall place at the corner of a public lot or ground, if there is such,
and if there is none, then at the corner of one of the inlots and at the corner
of each outlot, a good and sufficient stone of such size and dimensions and in
such manner as provided for under Ohio R.C. 711.01, for a corner from which to
make future surveys, and the point at which it may be found shall be designated
on the plat.
(Ord. 850. Passed 7-1-63.)
 
   (b)   Permanent Monuments. Such permanent markers shall be one-inch pipe or
steel rods set in and running through a concrete block at least six inches in
diameter and at least thirty inches long, and the bottom of such concrete block
shall be set at least thirty inches deep, below finished grade in the plat, and
the points at which they may be found shall be designated on the plat.
(Ord. 74-42. Passed 5-6-74.)
   (c)   Certification of Permanent Monuments. Before final acceptance of the
street improvements by the City or County, the subdivider or developer shall,
through a registered surveyor, certify to the City or County that all required
permanent monuments are correctly in place or that those removed during
construction have been replaced.
 
   (d)   Lot Corners. Iron pins shall be set at all lot corners by a registered
surveyor. (Ord. 850. Passed 7-1-63.)
 
   1250.10  APPROVAL AND ACCEPTANCE OF IMPROVEMENTS.
   (a)   The approval and acceptance of the improvements will be based upon
proper installation in accordance with the approved plans and specifications
and all requirements of these Regulations as reported by the City Engineer,
payment to the City for the cost of all inspection and tests and receipt by the
Clerk of Council of an acceptable maintenance bond in the amount of five
percent of the performance bond. The maintenance bond shall guarantee the
performance of the improvement for a period of one year after acceptance by
Council.
   The bond shall clearly define the work, and shall refer to construction
drawing numbers, the street and subdivision in which the installation is
located, and lineal feet of improvement installed.
   No new sewers or water mains and/or appurtenances shall be opened to
existing systems until the new installation has been accepted by Council.
(Ord. 78-108. Passed 2-19-79.)
   1250.11   STREET PAVEMENT SPECIFICATIONS.
   (a)   The compacted subgrade shall be approved earth and comply with the
State of Ohio Department of Transportation specifications Item 203, "Roadway
Excavation and Embankment".  (Ord. 76-5.  Passed 2-2-76.)
 
   (b)   The requirements for a public roadway in a residential district shall
be the minimum pavement width of twenty-eight feet measured from back of curb
to back of curb.  The concrete pavement shall be reinforced Portland cement
concrete pavement of a uniform thickness of seven inches, in accordance with
the latest edition of the State of Ohio Construction and Material
Specifications, Item 451.  The pavement shall be installed on a three-inch
thick compacted sub-base in accordance with ODOT Item 310 (as per the 1997
edition) or approved equal.
   The requirements for a public roadway in a Commercial or Industrial District
shall be the minimum pavement width of twenty-nine feet measured from back of
curb to back of curb.  The concrete pavement shall be reinforced Portland
cement concrete payment of a uniform thickness of nine inches, in accordance
with the latest edition of the State of Ohio Construction and Material
Specifications, Item 451.  The pavement shall be installed on a three-inch
thick compacted sub-base in accordance with ODOT Item 310 (as per the 1997
edition) or approved equal.
(Ord. 00-54.  Passed 10-10-00.)
   (c)   The longitudinal center construction joints for the concrete pavement
shall have a three-inch by one-inch key, one-half inch diameter by three-foot
long deformed billet steel bars spaced thirty inches on centers and one and
one-half inch by one-quarter inch asphalt filled joint.
 
   (d)   The transverse construction joints for the concrete pavement shall
have a three-inch by one-inch key and a one and one-half inch by one-quarter
inch asphalt filled joint. The slab shall be ten inches thick, with a length of
taper not less than twenty-four inches in length.
   (e)   The transverse contraction joints for the concrete pavement shall be
spaced not more than fifteen feet on centers and shall consist of a two and
one-half inch by one-quarter inch asphalt filled joint.
 
   (f)   The expansion joints for the concrete pavement shall be placed at all
intersections and shall have three-quarter inch diameter by twenty-four inch
long sleeved round smooth dowel bars painted and greased, spaced fifteen inches
on centers and a three-quarter inch joint. (Ord. 850. Passed 7-1-63.)
 
   (g)   The pavement shall have an integral mountable curb in accordance with
ODOT Item 609.04.  The pavement shall have a rigid four-inch diameter
perforated underdrain installed in accordance with ODOT Item 605.
(Ord. 99-34.  Passed 7-19-99.)
   1250.115 PAVEMENT REPLACEMENT SPECIFICATIONS.
   All means, methods and materials shall conform to the latest edition of the
Ohio Department of Transportation Construction and Material Specifications. 
   (a)   Concrete With Asphalt Street.  Pavement replacement will be as
follows:
(1)   Compacted sub-base per ODOT Item 203.
(2)   Seven-inch minimum concrete base per ODOT Item 305.
(3)   0.40 gal/sy tack coat per ODOT Item 407.
(4)   Two-inch minimum of asphaltic concrete per ODOT Item 404.
   (b)   Asphalt Street.  Pavement replacement will be as follows:
(1)   Compacted sub-base per ODOT Item 203.
(2)   Ten-inch minimum aggregate base per ODOT Item 304,
(3)   0.40 gal/sy prime coat per ODOT Item 408.
(4)   Four-inch minimum of asphaltic concrete per ODOT Item 404.
   (c)   Concrete Apron.  Pavement replacement will be as follows:
(1)   Residential drives.
         A.   Compacted sub-base per ODOT Item 203.
         B.   Six-inch minimum of plain Portland cement concrete per ODOT Item
452.
(2)   Commercial/industrial drives.
         A.   Compacted sub-base per ODOT Item 203.
         B.   Eight-inch minimum of plain Portland cement concrete per ODOT
Item 452.
   (d)   Asphalt Apron.  Pavement replacement will be as follows:
(1)   Residential drives.
         A.   Compacted sub-base per ODOT Item 203.
         B.   Five-inch minimum aggregate base per ODOT Item 304.
         C.   0.40 gal/sy prime coat per ODOT Item 408.
         D.   Two-inch minimum of asphaltic concrete per ODOT Item 404.
(2)   Commercial/industrial drives.
         A.   Compacted sub-base per ODOT Item 203.
         B.   Six-inch minimum aggregate base per ODOT Item 304.
         C.   0.40 gal/sy prime coat per ODOT Item 408.
         D.   Three-inch minimum of asphaltic concrete per ODOT Item 404.
   (e)   Stone Drives.  Pavement replacement will be as follows:
(1)   Compacted sub-base per ODOT Item 203.
(2)   Eight-inch minimum aggregate base per ODOT Item 408.
   (Ord. 87-15.  Passed 5-18-87.)
   1250.12  EXCAVATION AND BACKFILL FOR SEWERS AND WATER MAINS.
   These specifications for excavation and backfill are minimum requirements
and will cover most work in general. Special requirements for unusual
conditions shall be agreed upon at the time of submitting detail plans and
specifications.
   (a)   Trench Excavation. The trench excavation for both sewer and water pipe
bedding shall be true to line and grade, as shown on the plans. The banks of
the trench shall be kept as nearly vertical as possible and shall be properly
drained. The bottom of the trenches shall not be more than twenty-four inches
wider than the outside diameter of the pipe, with a minimum clearance between
the bottom of the pipe and the trench bottom of one-fourth of the pipe diameter
(but not less than six inches) in order that the pipe may be bedded in No. 8 or
304 stone or slag as described in backfill subsections (g), (h) or (i) hereof.
Shale, ledge rock, boulders and large stones shall be removed from the trench
to give a minimum clearance from pipe or fittings of six inches.
      (Ord. 76-5. Passed 2-2-76.)
   (b)   Unstable Ground. Wherever wet, unstable or other undesirable soil is
encountered which does not provide proper bearing for pipe, such material shall
be excavated to good ground and the excavation refilled with suitable material
to the required subgrade, compacting the fill in six-inch layers. If it would
be more economical and desirable, soft ground may be crossed by supporting the
pine on concrete cradles, poured to cover the lower quadrant of the pipe. In no
case shall any pipe or appurtenances be laid in or on topsoil.
   (c)   Unauthorized Excavation. Wherever excavation in good ground has been
carried below the established grade for installation of the piping, such
excavated space shall be refilled with suitable material, as approved by the
City Engineer, to the required subgrade, compacting the fill in six-inch
layers.
   (d)   Sheeting, Shoring and Bracing. All excavation shall be adequately
protected from caving. If such caving occurs and disturbs the bedding, the
grade or the alignment of the piping, the work shall be removed, suitable
sheeting, shoring and bracing provided, and the work reinstalled. 
      The sheeting and bracing, in general, shall be removed as backfilling
progresses and in such a manner as to avoid caving of the trench. Voids left by
the withdrawal of sheeting shall be carefully filled and tamped.
   (e)   Excavation Under Railroad Tracks. Excavation under railroad tracks
shall be determined separately for each individual crossing and shall be shown
on the plans and described in the specifications.
   (f)   Tunnel Excavations. Where the excavation crosses main highways or
railroad tracks, tunneling may be permitted where depth of trench and soil
conditions are adequate. All tunnel backfill shall be of proper moisture
content to compact readily and shall be thoroughly tamped and rammed under,
around and over the pipe from the floor of the tunnel to the sidewalls and top
thereof. Where tunneling is to be used, the method and details shall be shown
in the plans and specifications.
      (Ord. 850. Passed 7-1-63.)
   (g)   Backfill for Water Mains. After the piping has been laid to line and
grade, trenches shall be backfllled with No. 8 or 304 limestone, carefully
deposited under and on both sides of the pipe, thoroughly and carefully rammed
by hand tamping methods until such fill has been brought to the center line of
pipe. Then, fine, loose earth shall be placed and thoroughly and carefully
rammed by hand tamping methods until such fill has been brought to six inches
above the pipe. This portion of the backfill shall be carefully placed and
thoroughly compacted until a firm and continuous support on the bottom and
sides is secured.
      Where the trench is excavated through cinder fill or other material
which, in the opinion of the inspector, is not suitable for backfill, suitable
material for backfilling shall be hauled to the site. The remainder of the
trench may then be backfilled by hand or mechanical equipment. Water settling
may be permitted if it is possible to do so without floating the pipe.
   (h)   Backfill for Sanitary Sewers. After sewer piping has been approved for
line and grade, trenches shall be backfilled with No. 8 or 304 limestone or
slag, carefully deposited under and around the pipe, thoroughly and carefully
rammed by hand tamping methods until enough limestone or slag fill has been
placed to provide a cover of at least six inches above the top of the pipe.
This backfill shall provide a firm and continuous support on the bottom and
sides of the pipe.
      The remainder of the backfill shall consist of material previously
excavated and may be placed by hand or mechanical equipment. Water settling
will be permitted, providing floating of the pipe does not occur.
   (i)   Backfill for Storm Sewers. After sewer piping has been approved for
line and grade, trenches shall be backfilled with No. 8 or 304 limestone or
slag, carefully deposited under and around the pipe, thoroughly and carefully
rammed by hand tamping methods until enough limestone or slag fill has been
placed to extend up around the pipe a distance from the bottom of the pipe
shown in the minimum bedding depth table as follows:
Minimum Bedding Depth for Pipe
 
Internal Diameter (Inches) Bedding Depth (Inches)
12                         4
15                         4
18                         5
21                         6
24                         7
27                         8
30                         9
33                         10
36                         10
39                         11
42                         11
48                         12
54                         13
60                         13
   (j)   Backfill in Paved Areas. Wherever trenches occur in existing roadways
and paved areas, the backfill shall consist of No. 8 or 304 stone. It shall be
thoroughly compacted in six-inch layers, or puddled with hose and long nozzles,
after the backfill is in place. When the area is to be paved with asphalt, the
top eight inches of the backfill shall consist of crushed slag or limestone to
match the existing road base and shall then be paved to match existing road or
paved area. For all concrete pavement, the concrete must project at least one
foot beyond the trench sides.
      Wherever trenches occur in future paved areas, the backfill shall be as
per the foregoing paragraph or in accordance with subsection (g), (h) or (i)
hereof if left unpaved for a period of at least six months after completion of
the backfill.
      (Ord. 76-5. Passed 2-2-76.)
   1250.13   WATER MAIN SPECIFICATIONS.
   (EDITOR’S NOTE:  The specifications were amended according to Exhibit A of
Ordinance 2014-49 and are incorporated within the Clerk of Council’s official
recordings.)
   1250.14  SANITARY SEWER SPECIFICATIONS.
   (a)   Pipe and Fittings. Pipe and fittings shall be vitrified clay, asbestos
cement, or polyvinyl chloride material of a strength suitable to withstand the
loads applied.  The joints shall be gasketed using a compression ring.
   The selected materials, together with the applicable ASTM Specification
numbers, shall be indicated on the drawings after conferring with the City
Engineer. (Ord. 74-42. Passed 5-6-74.)
   (b)   Manholes. Manholes shall be constructed in accordance with the
"Standard Manhole" shown in the State of Ohio, Department of Transportation,
Construction and Material Specifications, January 1, 1975 edition, as amended,
and the Division of Highways, Bureau of Roadway Design, Standard Construction
Drawing, as amended by Council, except where they specifically deviate from
other ordinances duly enacted by the City. Precast concrete manholes are
preferred. (Ord. 75-72A. Passed 9-8-75.)
   (c)   Pipe Laying. The bedding of No. 8 or 304 limestone or slag shall be
placed in such a manner as to assure full support along the lower quadrant of
the pipe barrel only and not in the bells. As the pipe is laid, each length
shall be checked for alignment and grade. Pipe laying shall proceed upgrade
with spigot ends pointing in the direction of flow.
   A defective pipe, or pipe which has had its line or grade disturbed
sufficiently to open the joint after laying, shall be taken up and replaced.
All open ends in the pipe shall be stoppered. Stoppers shall have the same
joints as the sewer pipe and shall be installed in wyes as the work progresses
and in the pipe line when the work is not in progress.
   Wye branches shall be installed for each property and a record of actual
locations shall be given to the City Engineer so that they may be recorded. All
wyes shall be closed with stoppers described above. All house connections shall
be made with the same materials and method of installation as herein described
for the mains. In new developments, branch lines from main line wyes for house
sewers shall be installed from the main to the sideline of the street right of
way, at the time of installing the main sewer. (Ord. 76-5. Passed 2-2-76.)
   1250.15  STORM SEWER SPECIFICATIONS.
   (a)   Pipe. The pipe shall be vitrified tile, asbestos cement, polyvinyl
chloride, plain concrete or reinforced concrete, whichever the conditions of
loading may require, and shall be so stipulated by the drawings and
specifications.
(Ord. 76-5. Passed 2-2-76.)
   (b)   Manholes and Inlets. The manholes and inlets shall be constructed in
accordance with the State of Ohio, Department of Transportation, Construction
and Material Specifications, January 1, 1975 edition, as amended, and the
Division of Highways, Bureau of Roadway Design, Standard Construction Drawing,
as amended by Council, except where they specifically deviate from other
ordinances duly enacted by the City. Precast concrete manholes are the
preferred type.
(Ord. 75-72A. Passed 9-8-75.)
   (c)   Pipe Laying. The bedding of No. 8 or 304 limestone or slag shall be
placed in such a manner to assure full support along the lower quadrant of the
pipe barrel. As the pipe is laid, each length shall be checked for alignment
and grade. Pipe laying shall proceed upgrade with spigot ends pointing in the
direction of flow. A defective pipe, or pipe which has had its line or grade
disturbed sufficiently to open the joint after laying, shall be taken up and
replaced. All open ends in the pipe shall be stoppered and all joints shall be
waterproof.
(Ord. 76-5. Passed 2-2-76.)
   1250.16   TESTING AND INSPECTION.
   (a)   Sanitary Sewerage and Water Lines. Field tests shall be conducted
before the systems are placed in service by the City Engineer. The tests shall
be performed as specified herein, in the presence of a representative of the
City Engineer. Preliminary tests and repair or correction of all faulty work
shall be completed before calling the representative to observe the test for
acceptance.
   Disposal of testing media must be done with full consideration to flooding
or damage to the piping, other installations, adjoining property and safety of
personnel.
(1)   Testing equipment. All necessary apparatus and equipment required for
testing, including pumps, barrels, gauges, mirrors, temporary lines and
fittings, shall be furnished by the person or persons constructing the sanitary
sewers, water mains and/or appurtenances thereto.
(2)   Water lines. The piping shall be tested hydrostatically and permissible
leakage shall be as specified in the AWWA Standard which is evaluated for a
pressure basis of 150 psi. Permissible leakage shall not be more than thirty
U.S. gallons per twenty-four hours per mile of pipe per inch of nominal
diameter of pipe.
   The City water piping shall be thoroughly sterilized with chlorine and
flushed before it is placed in operation. The chlorinating materials shall be
introduced to the City water piping under the direction of the City Engineer.
Following a contact period of not less than twenty-four hours, the piping shall
be flushed with clean water until the residual chlorine content is not greater
than two-tenths ppm. Tests for efficacy of sterilization shall be made by the
City and repeated sterilization shall be performed by those installing the work
as required.
(3)   Sanitary sewerage. All sewers shall be constructed and so jointed that
infiltration of water into, or leakage of sewage therefrom, shall not be
greater than hereinafter specified when subjected to the following leakage
test:
After sewers, or sections thereof, have been constructed and the backfilling
has been sufficiently completed to prevent flotation of the pipe, and at times
and locations selected by the City Engineer, sections of the sewer shall be
isolated and the test shall be made by plugging the downgrade end of the
section to be tested and a temporarily installed curve, or other fitting, shall
be used at the other end so that the station to be tested can be filled with
water with four feet of head at the upper end for a period of one hour.
The four feet of head shall be measured above the crown of the pipe, and in
cases where the ground water table is higher than the sewer, the four feet of
head shall be measured above the water table.
These isolated sections of sewer shall be from manhole to manhole in order to
test only the sewer pipe, and the maximum rate of exfiltration shall be 100
gallons per inch of diameter of pipe per twenty-four hours per mile of pipe.
Manholes shall be plugged and tested separately. The maximum ground water
infiltration for a manhole four feet in diameter shall be 0.291 gallons per
vertical foot per hour.
      Before the leakage test, the sewer shall be subject to a test for grade,
line and cleanliness. The City Engineer may require that the interior of the
sewer be photographed or examined by television at the expense of the
subdivider.
   All obstructions found in the sewer shall be removed and irregularities in
line and grade shall be straightened.
   (b)   Concrete Pavement. Compression test cylinders shall be made by the
inspector each day. If further tests are deemed necessary by the City Engineer,
he shall so direct that these be made in addition to the compression tests. If
the cylinders do not show the required compressive strength is attained,
borings of the pavement shall be required, and if these show the pavement to
have less than the required compressive strength, the pavement shall be removed
and replaced.
(Ord. 850. Passed 7-1-63; Ord. 74-42. Passed 5-6-74; Ord. 76-5. Passed 2-2-76.)
